description: From Middle English chargen, from Old French chargier, from Late Latin carricō (“to load”), from Latin carrus (“a car, wagon”); see car. Doublet of cargo.

entries.meaning: The amount of money levied for a service.
examples: There will be a charge of five dollars.

entries.meaning: (military) A ground attack against a prepared enemy.
examples: Pickett's Charge; the Charge of the Light Brigade

entries.meaning: A forceful forward movement.
An official description (by the police or a court) of a crime that somebody may be guilty of.
examples: two charges of manslaughter

entries.meaning: An accusation by a person or organization.
examples: we'll nail the sophist to it, if we can get him on that charge;

entries.meaning: (electromagnetism, chemistry) An electric charge.
The scope of someone's responsibility.
examples: The child was in the nanny's charge.

entries.meaning: Someone or something entrusted to one's care, such as a child to a babysitter or a student to a teacher.
examples: The child was a charge of the nanny.

entries.meaning: A load or burden; cargo.
examples: The ship had a charge of colonists and their belongings.

entries.meaning: An instruction.
examples: I gave him the charge to get the deal closed by the end of the month.

entries.meaning: (basketball) An offensive foul in which the player with the ball moves into a stationary defender.
(firearms) A measured amount of powder and/or shot in a cartridge.
(by extension) A measured amount of explosive.
(heraldry) An image displayed on an escutcheon.
(weaponry) A position (of a weapon) fitted for attack.
examples: to bring a weapon to the charge

entries.meaning: (farriery) A sort of plaster or ointment.
(obsolete) Weight; import; value.
(historical or obsolete) A measure of thirty-six pigs of lead, each pig weighing about seventy pounds; a charre.
(ecclesiastical) An address given at a church service concluding a visitation.
(slang, uncountable) Cannabis.
examples: At about the same time I went off pills and started smoking charge marijuana, you know.

verbs.description: charge (third-person singular simple present charges, present participle charging, simple past and past participle charged)

entries.meaning: To assign a duty or responsibility to.
examples: Moses  […]  charged you to love the Lord your God.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To assign (a debit) to an account.
examples: Let's charge this to marketing.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To pay on account, as by using a credit card.
examples: Can I charge my purchase to my credit card?
Can I charge this purchase?

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To require payment (of) (a price or fee, for goods, services, etc.).
examples: to charge high for goods
I won't charge you for the wheat.

entries.meaning: (dated) To sell at a given price.
examples: to charge coal at $5 per unit

entries.meaning: (law) To formally accuse (a person) of a crime.
examples: I'm charging you with assault and battery.

entries.meaning: To impute or ascribe.
To call to account; to challenge.

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To place a burden, load or responsibility on or in.

entries.meaning: To ornament with or cause to bear.
examples: to charge an architectural member with a moulding

entries.meaning: (heraldry) To assume as a bearing.
examples: He charges three roses.

entries.meaning: (heraldry) To add to or represent on.
examples: He charges his shield with three roses or.

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To load equipment with material required for its use, as a firearm with powder, a fire hose with water, a chemical reactor with raw materials.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to take on an electric charge.
examples: Rubbing amber with wool will charge it quickly.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To replenish energy to (a battery, or a device containing a battery) by use of an electrical device plugged into a power outlet.
examples: He charged the battery overnight.
Don't forget to charge the drill.
I charge my phone every night.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of a battery or a device containing a battery) To replenish energy.
examples: The battery is still charging: I can't use it yet.
His cell phone charges very quickly, whereas mine takes forever.

definitionGroups.group: (intransitive) To move forward quickly and forcefully, particularly in combat and/or on horseback.

entries.meaning: (military, transitive and intransitive) To attack by moving forward quickly in a group.
examples: The impetuous corps charged the enemy lines.

entries.meaning: (basketball) To commit a charging foul.
(cricket, of a batsman) To take a few steps down the pitch towards the bowler as they deliver the ball, either to disrupt the length of the delivery, or to get into a better position to hit the ball.
(transitive, of a hunting dog) To lie on the belly and be still. (A command given by a hunter to a dog)
